message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of hypercortisolism, such as weight gain, hirsutism, ecchymotic patches, and muscle weakness. The high blood pressure and hypokalemia support the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. Primary hyperaldosteronism also causes hypertension and hypokalemia, but it does not typically present with the other symptoms. Polycystic ovarian syndrome can cause irregular menses, but it is not associated with hypercortisolism. Hypothyroidism does not typically cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by facial hair, ecchymotic patches, and muscle weakness. The abnormal lab values, including elevated glucose, low potassium, and high sodium, also support this diagnosis. Primary hyperaldosteronism would present with hypertension and hypokalemia but without the other symptoms present in this case. Polycystic ovarian syndrome may cause irregular menses and weight gain but would not explain the other symptoms. Hypothyroidism may cause fatigue and irregular menses but would not explain the other physical findings or abnormal lab values.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms such as irregular menses, facial hair, and elevated blood pressure that suggests Cushing syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol secretion. The weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles is consistent with proximal muscle weakness seen in Cushing syndrome. The lab values such as low potassium and high glucose also indicate Cushing syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms such as irregular menses, facial hair, ecchymotic patches, and laboratory findings such as low potassium and high glucose, which suggest Cushing syndrome. Primary hyperaldosteronism would present with hypertension and hypokalemia, which are not the primary symptoms in this case. Polycystic ovarian syndrome would present with irregular menses and signs of hyperandrogenism, but would not necessarily present with hypertension or muscle weakness. Hypothyroidism may present with fatigue and irregular menses, but would not present with the other symptoms such as facial hair and ecchymotic patches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has irregular menses, facial hair, acne, ecchymotic patches, and weakness of muscles. All of these are symptoms of Cushing syndrome, which is caused by excessive cortisol production. The lab values also support this diagnosis, as the serum glucose is elevated and the potassium level is low, which is commonly seen in Cushing syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by adrenal gland hypersecretion of cortisol. The patient has facial hair and ecchymotic patches, which are common symptoms of Cushing syndrome. The weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles is also consistent with Cushing syndrome. Elevated serum glucose levels are common in Cushing syndrome as well. None of the other options match the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has irregular menses, facial hair, and a high BMI, which are all common symptoms of Cushing syndrome. The high blood pressure and weakness of the iliopsoas and biceps muscles also suggest Cushing syndrome. The laboratory values are consistent with Cushing syndrome as well, as the patient has hypokalemia and hyperglycemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple symptoms that are consistent with Cushing syndrome, such as facial hair, acne, ecchymotic patches, weakness of muscles, and hypertension. The laboratory values also suggest hyperglycemia and hypokalemia, which are common in Cushing syndrome. Primary hyperaldosteronism may cause hypertension, but the laboratory values do not support it. Polycystic ovarian syndrome may cause irregular menses, but it does not typically cause hypertension or muscle weakness. Hypothyroidism may cause fatigue, but it does not typically cause hypertension, muscle weakness, or hyperglycemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, irregular menses, hypertension, facial hair growth, and muscle weakness. Primary hyperaldosteronism usually presents with hypokalemia, and polycystic ovarian syndrome typically presents with infertility and ovarian cysts. Hypothyroidism may present with fatigue but usually has other characteristic symptoms such as cold intolerance and weight gain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by a combination of obesity, hypertension, irregular menses, hirsutism, easy bruising, and weakness of proximal muscles. The low potassium and high glucose levels are also consistent with Cushing syndrome. None of the other options explain the full range of symptoms.
